column1: Does more fast food in the neighborhood up diabetes risk?
column3: Living in an area with lots of fast-food spots is associated with a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes, research on veterans indicates.

column1: Giant kelp loses nutritional value in warmer seas
column3: As sea temperatures rise, the nutritional value of giant kelp decreases. That has far-reaching effects for the global food chain.

column1: Lidar reveals nearly 500 ancient ceremonial sites in Mexico
column3: Researchers have discovered nearly 500 ancient ceremonial sites in Mexico. They're similar to Aguada Fénix, the largest and oldest Maya monument ever found.

column1: COVID lockdowns gave some teen girls a break from stress
column3: COVID-19 lockdowns gave many teen girls a mental health boost by giving them a break from their busy lives. They even got more sleep.

column1: When just a few termites take the bait, it kills the whole colony
column3: It only takes a few termites consuming poisonous bait to eliminate an entire colony, a study of 1.68 million termites shows.

column1: EEG helps predict if treatment will benefit people with epilepsy
column3: A new diagnostic model that combines EEG with clinical observation can determine if patients with epilepsy will respond to treatment with 80% accuracy.

column1: Are you really smart, or is it just Google?
column3: We may be losing the ability to perceive our own intelligence because we can quickly google the answer to just about any question.

column1: Salamander size is a big part of their incredible healing
column3: Salamanders can heal without scarring. A new discovery about the role their size plays in the process could lead to ways to heal burns without scars.

column1: Is trick-or-treating safe this Halloween?
column3: What does the uptick of COVID among kids mean for trick-or-treating this year? An expert says enjoy Halloween, but keep some safety measures in mind.

column1: Smell and memory are behind all the pumpkin spice love
column3: Why do so many people go gaga over pumpkin spice each fall? Two researchers say that scent and its connection to memory is the key.

column1: ‘Surge buyers’ of guns more likely to think of suicide
column3: First-time gun owners who bought a gun during the pandemic were more likely than established gun owners to report lifetime and past-year suicidal ideation.

column1: 6 ways to deal with alcoholism stigma in recovery
column3: Americans in recovery for alcoholism face a double stigma of not drinking socially and problem drinking. These six strategies may help, say researchers.

column1: ‘Tobacco-free’ nicotine claims may lure young adults
column3: The claim of tobacco-free nicotine, from the brand Puff Bar may make young adults think e-cigarettes are less harmful, research finds.

column1: ‘Weird’ ancient mammal is the first to have tusks
column3: We were able to show that the first tusks belonged to animals that came before modern mammals, called dicynodonts, researchers report.

column1: Tool could close gap in breast cancer prediction for Black women
column3: There's been a lack of breast cancer prediction tools tailored to Black women. A new simple to use online tool changes that.

column1: Survey: College grad job market is on the rebound in 2021
column3: An annual survey of employers shows that college grads may have an easier time finding jobs in 2021 than they did in the first year of the COVID pandemic.

column1: Heartburn drugs may cut gum disease severity
column3: Proton pump inhibitors, drugs prescribed for heartburn, could have a beneficial effect on gum disease, according to new research.

column1: Is it time to ditch daylight saving time?
column3: Daylight saving time comes with a host of negative consequences. Should the United States scrap DST? An expert weighs in.

column1: AI and night vision reveal the secrets of spider webs
column3: Researchers used night vision and AI to watch spiders use millions of individual leg actions to blindly create intricate webs using only the sense of touch.

column1: Adults aren’t great at discerning kid emotions
column3: A new tool assesses how well people recognize emotion in elementary school-aged children. It seems adults aren't very good at it.

column1: How some polluters work around the rules
column3: Local and state agencies generally monitor air quality on an intermittent schedule, such as once every six days. Here's what happens on the other days.

column1: Competition drives the gender pay gap? Maybe not
column3: New research investigates the theory that women aren't as competitive as men, and that this contributes to the gender wage gap.

column1: Laying low might have saved ground critters from dino-killing asteroid
column3: An asteroid that struck Earth 66 million years ago killed nearly all dinosaurs, plants, and animals. So how did some creatures survive the mass extinction?

column1: Warnings on sugary drinks could cut weight gain and health costs
column3: Warning labels on soda and other sugar-sweetened drinks could prevent weight gain and reduce medical costs. But the benefits aren't expected to last.

column1: Physical therapy after knee surgery reduces opioid addiction risk
column3: Even low levels of physical therapy may lower the likelihood of long-term opioid use after total knee replacement, a study of 67,000 patient records shows.

column1: Physical therapy reduces opioid addiction risk after knee surgery
column3: Even low levels of physical therapy may lower the likelihood of long-term opioid use after total knee replacement, a study of 67,000 patient records shows.

column1: Mutant microbe produces carbon-neutral biofuel
column3: Researchers have modified a microbe so it can make a biofuel using only three ingredients: carbon dioxide, solar panel-generated electricity, and light.

column1: How bilingual brains switch languages seamlessly
column3: For people who are bilingual, speaking one language and then another comes naturally, because their brain doesn't detect the language has switched,

column1: Brain’s immune system may not be to blame for FASD
column3: The bain's immune system may not be at the root of fetal alcohol spectrum disorders, which can cause children lifetime physical and cognitive impairments.

column1: Being nice to others makes them more likely to be nice to you
column3: New research finds that people tend to reciprocate each other's behavior. A person who acts friendly and sociable is more likely get the same in return.

column1: Lack of whale poop has major impact on ocean ecosystems
column3: Fifty years later, scientists are still discovering the consequences of whale hunting. New findings reveal how the giants' absence affects the ecosystem.

column1: Do monogenetic volcanoes threaten the southwestern US?
column3: Monogenetic volcanoes erupt just once, for a few days or for decades. New research examines their presence in the Southwestern US.

column1: Atacama desert plants may hold clues to saving crops
column3: Plants that thrive in the harsh Atacama desert are a genetic goldmine for engineering crops for our dry future, say researchers.

column1: 2 things cause weak quads after ACL surgery
column3: Weak quadriceps after ACL surgery isn't only the result of muscle atrophy. New research uncovers a second cause.

column1: COVID-19 had a surprising effect on 2020 US election
column3: A new study of the US 2020 election shows that Donald Trump actually lost more ground to Joe Biden in counties that experienced fewer COVID-19 cases,

column1: Comet’s intense heat turned sand to glass 12,000 years ago
column3: Heat from a comet exploding just above the ground in what is now the Atacama Desert in Chile fused sandy soil into patches of glass around 12,000 yeas ago.

column1: Young people get less sex ed now than 25 years ago
column3: A significant number of young people in the US receive no sex ed information about birth control and STI prevention before they have sexual intercourse.

column1: 250,000-year-old skull raises questions about human origins
column3: A child’s skull believed to be up to 250,000 years old and discovered in a South African cave sheds light on a human ancestor called Homo naledi.

column1: Copper and drug combo may treat deadly brain tumors in kids
column3: Combing copper and a drug once used to treat alcoholism may offer a way to treat children with medulloblastoma, a common but deadly form of brain tumor.

column1: 5 ways to turn your anxiety into something useful
column3: The author of a new book has some tips on how you can transform your anxiety into a superpower. One tip is as simple as looking at your phone less.

column1: Skylights are an untapped resource for heating homes
column3: Calculations indicate that passive solar systems could offer a third of the heat needed to warm homes in the United States.

column1: Can emotional support lower veterans’ suicide risk?
column3: Veterans who have a greater sense of optimism about life and who receive emotional support from loved ones may be less likely to develop suicidal thoughts.

column1: El Niño can leave more children hungry than COVID did
column3: A single bad El Niño weather event can leave nearly 6 million children undernourished, according to a new study.

column1: Telehealth during COVID was a mixed bag for some nursing home residents
column3: The use of telehealth at nursing homes during the COVID-19 pandemic proved a plus for some residents. But it's not a one-size-fits-all solution.

column1: Why older adults have a higher risk of severe COVID-19
column3: The same cellular mechanism that puts the elderly at higher risk of infection and death from COVID-19 could potentially be used to protect them.

column1: Popular heart failure drug may not work better than cheaper version
column3: Sacubitril/valsartan may work for patients with mild or moderate heart failure, but no better than valsartan alone for patients with severe cases.

column1: Driving through defense ups risk of ACL tears for NBA players
column3: A close look at ACL tears in the NBA shows that basketball players who drive to the hoop more often have a higher risk of knee injury.

column1: Electronic dating violence starts as early as 12
column3: Electronic dating violence, including harassment, coercion, and monitoring, peaks in teens around age 16, but then begins to gradually decline.

column1: This personality type knowingly shares fake news
column3: New research indicates that a particular personality type is given to sharing fake news despite warnings.

column1: Corporate sustainability fails by selling more stuff
column3: A new book examines how corporate sustainability efforts have failed. Selling lots of green products is, after all, still untenable consumerism.

column1: Simple blood test predicts recovery time after hip replacement
column3: A simple blood test and a smartwatch worn before and after hip replacement surgery can help predict when patients will get back on their feet.

column1: Magnetic brain stim leads to remission for patients with severe depression
column3: The new treatment for severe depression works well, it works quickly, and it's noninvasive, says Nolan Williams. It could be a game changer.

column1: How to lessen seasonal affective disorder symptoms
column3: As the days get shorter and we're exposed to less daylight, an expert explains light's role in seasonal affective disorder and how to lessen its symptoms.

column1: Can the western US avoid a future of low or no snow?
column3: If the planet continues to warm, low-to-no-snow winters will become a regular occurrence on certain mountains in the western US in 35 to 60 years.

column1: Microwaves and other small noises really stress out your dog
column3: Fireworks and thunderstorms aren't the only noises that can stress out your dog. Common household noises from vacuums and microwaves can, too.

column1: Team links sitting during COVID to depression symptoms
column3: People who continued to sit more as COVID-19 continued were more likely to have depression symptoms. Sitting is a sneaky behavior, says Jacob Meyer.

column1: Fossil elephant cranium reveals its competitive edge
column3: A fossil elephant cranium from Kenya weighs roughly two tons and reveals adaptations that let its species, Loxodonta adaurora, outcompete others.

column1: Depression screening at school ups odds of treatment
column3: Universal school-based screening for depressive symptoms increases both identification and the start of treatment for adolescent depression, research finds.

column1: What’s behind the global K-pop and Korean film takeover?
column3: Between the popular show Squid Game and the rise of K-pop bands like BTS, South Korean media is everywhere. Here, a scholar explains the boom.

column1: Many claims about sex differences lack scientific rigor
column3: ...an alarming percentage of claims of sex differences are not backed by sufficient evidence. Researchers call for raising the bar.

column1: Watch: Solar fuel refinery is ‘no science fiction’
column3: A solar mini-refinery that can turn sunlight and air into carbon-neutral fuels has proven its effectiveness over the course of years, researchers say.

column1: Radiotherapy may explain heart disease in childhood cancer survivors
column3: Long after surviving childhood cancer, some otherwise healthy young adults go on to develop cardiometabolic disease. Radiation may be to blame.

column1: Starfish larva inspires drug delivery microrobot
column3: A microrobot that mimics the movement of a starfish larva may one day lead to microswimmers that can deliver drugs to diseased cells with pinpoint accuracy.

column1: Deep biosphere holds secrets to evolutionary history
column3: Understanding the history of the deep biosphere can provide insight into the evolution of life on Earth.

column1: Metamaterial can sense, decide, and act
column3: Researchers report a metamaterial that can respond to its environment, independently make a decision, and perform an action without direction from a human.

column1: Don’t pressure a picky eater, ARFID survey shows
column3: Adults who would likely have been diagnosed with ARFID confirm standard advice not to force a picky eater.

column1: How to keep sea lions out of the woods and off porches
column3: Better understanding sea lions' habitat in New Zealand could help the population rebound but not get into so much trouble.

column1: ‘Eggshell planets’ are probably not right for life
column3: Eggshell planets have an ultra-thin outer brittle layer and probably no plate tectonics. That raises questions about their habitability.

column1: Why Europe’s trees lack New England’s pop of red in fall
column3: Each fall, the leaves of almost half of North America's species of trees and shrubs turn red. But the same isn't true in England. A botanist explains why.

column1: Human wastewater takes a heavy toll on coastal ecosystems
column3: Most of us don't think about what happens after we flush the toilet. Results of a deep dive into the environmental impact of human wastewater aren't pretty.

column1: Which US veterans are most at risk of food insecurity?
column3: Food insecurity is estimated to affect up to 24% of US military veterans, but risks are significantly higher for people of color and women.

column1: Avoiding expensive colleges due to ‘tuition myopia’ can backfire
column3: Students who choose a low-cost, low-return college over an expensive one may experience lower lifetime income and higher risk of bankruptcy later.

column1: Salt causes surprising reaction deep in the brain
column3: New research clarifies how salt intake affects the brain and the relationship between neuron activity and blood flow deep in the brain.

column1: Team uses AI to develop the ‘ultimate’ chickpea
column3: Researchers used artificial intelligence to create a new genetic model for the ultimate chickpea that has the potential to lift crop yields by up to 12%.

column1: A little caffeine linked to lower gestational diabetes risk
column3: Drinking up to 100 mg of caffeine a day during the second trimester of pregnancy was associated with a 47% reduction in gestational diabetes risk.

column1: College student voting jumped in 2020 presidential election
column3: ...despite a global pandemic, and systemic challenges throughout our democracy, college students are supporting each other to participate....

column1: School leadership turnover cuts research-based practices
column3: School leadership turnover is worst for the brokering of research evidence in lower-performing schools working to improve outcomes for young people, research finds.

column1: To decontaminate your mask, pop it in the oven
column3: Want to decontaminate your disposable mask? Researchers report that all you have to do is heat it to 160 degrees Fahrenheit in the oven for five minutes.

column1: Near-Earth asteroid might be a little piece of the moon
column3: The near-Earth asteroid Kamo`oalewa might be a lost piece of the moon. This spring, we got much needed follow-up observations and went, 'Wow it is real.'

column1: Secondhand clothing is big business, but is it truly green?
column3: ThredUp says the secondhand clothing market could exceed $50 billion in revenue by 2023. What's the most sustainable way to do business?

column1: Will supply chain troubles ruin your Thanksgiving?
column3: In light of supply chain issues, how can you prepare for the possibility of limited ingredients for your Thanksgiving feast? First of all, don't freak out.

column1: Inflammation from obesity may raise gum disease risk
column3: Research in mice shows inflammation obesity causes may lead to the development of bone-destroying cells that can break down the bone holding teeth in place.

column1: Stem cell transplants without chemo and radiation first?
column3: A new approach to stem cell transplants that doesn't require radiation or chemotherapy shows promise in mice, report researchers.

column1: Team creates ‘elusive’ poppy molecule in the lab
column3: Researchers report synthesizing setigerumine I, an alkaloid molecule found in trace amounts in the poppy family Papaveraceae.

column1: Earth’s temps today are ‘unprecedented’ in 24,000 years
column3: The magnitude and rate of Earth's warming temperature over the last 150 years far surpasses the magnitude and rate of changes over the last 24,000 years.

column1: X-rays may save Henry VIII’s revered ship, the Mary Rose
column3: Bacteria and chemicals are eating away at the crown jewel of Henry VIII's 16th century fleet, the Mary Rose. A new X-ray method may help save her.

column1: Young American adults report having fewer sexual partners
column3: A survey finds that fewer young adults report having more than one sexual partner in the last year and growth in the number who report abstaining.

column1: Protein-RNA droplets act like Silly Putty
column3: Liquid droplets of protein and RNA have traits like those of Silly Putty, say researchers.

column1: Air pollution hampers how well your brain performs
column3: New research indicates that even short-term exposure to air pollution can affect how well the brain performs and work productivity.

column1: Wildfire drives ‘refugee’ trees to cooler, wetter ground
column3: As climate conditions change, tree species are migrating to cooler or wetter sites. Wildfire is speeding up the process, a new study finds.

column1: Could engineered gut bacteria guard our mood?
column3: Researchers are working toward genetically engineered bacteria that monitor chemical production from inside a person's gut and fix any imbalances.

column1: This Thanksgiving, thank your past self
column3: Expressing gratitute to your past self may offer an increase in the self-awareness measures of clarity, authenticity, and connectedness.

column1: Team solves Darwin’s finch yellow beak mystery
column3: Some of Darwin's finch nestlings have a yellow beak. The discovery of why that is may offer clues about the differences in how species evolve.

column1: Tropical deforestation could boost risk of heat-related deaths
column3: The increase in heat-related deaths would be comparable to mortality from other long-term public health challenges in Asia, such as tobacco smoking.

column1: Boredom kept people smoking more during COVID-19
column3: Cigarette sales in the US rose last year for the first time in 20 years. Stress and boredom during COVID-19 played a role in people smoking more.

column1: How long will the supply chain crunch last?
column3: An expert explains when the current supply chain problems might end and how the current crisis has been years and years in the making.

column1: Finger snaps are one of the fastest motions humans can create
column3: The finger snap occurs in only seven milliseconds, more than twenty times faster than the blink of an eye, which takes more than 150 milliseconds.

column1: New method flags false positives in COVID-19 test results
column3: A new procedure that targets false-positive COVID-19 test results could prevent unneeded quarantines and repeated testing, researchers say.

column1: Electric vehicle owners could sell power back to the grid
column3: Electric vehicles could send energy back to power grids while they're parked, researchers report. The process could also save owners money each year.

column1: Frailty is more common in kids getting heart surgery than previously known
column3: A third of children who undergo a procedure for a severe congenital heart condition identify as frail. That can affect their health outcomes after surgery.

column1: Letting teens consent on their own may boost HPV vaccine rates
column3: More teenagers might get the HPV vaccine if they could do so without involvement of their parents, a new study shows.

column1: How Galápagos giant tortoises live cancer-free for 100 years
column3: Extra genes may be the secret to aging well for Galápagos giant tortoises, which can weigh over 300 pounds and live cancer-free for more than 100 years.

column1: Lemurs confirm benefits of ‘poop soup’ for ailing gut
column3: Lemurs confirm the benefit of fecal transplants for off-kilter gut microbiomes. The treatment sounds gross but is effective, say researchers.

column1: ‘Volcanic winter’ contributed to mass extinction 250 million years ago
column3: A volcanic winter that drastically lowered Earth's temperatures, likely contributed to the mass extinction that happened 250 million years ago.

column1: How Native American plant meds treat pain and diarrhea
column3: New research examines the molecular workings of plants that Californian Native Americans have long used to treat pain and diarrhea.

column1: Genes may hold clues to keep broccoli fresh
column3: New research identifies the genes that cause broccoli to age after harvest. The work could lead to ways to keep broccoli fresh longer.
